metadata.personalization_note: This is base content. LLM personalization layer adds visa-specific context, cultural bridges, and localized examples at runtime.

modules.name: Banking Fundamentals
modules.description: Understanding the US banking system, account types, and essential banking operations

lessons.title: US Currency and Money Basics
learning_objectives: Identify US paper currency denominations
Recognize and value US coins
Understand that displayed prices exclude sales tax
Perform basic currency calculations

content.text: The United States dollar (USD) is the official currency, divided into 100 cents. The dollar sign ($) precedes amounts. Unlike many countries, US currency notes are uniform in size and predominantly green, requiring attention to printed denominations.

rows: Large purchases - some businesses do not accept
content.note: The $2 bill exists but is rarely circulated.

content.important: The dime (10 cents) is physically smaller than the nickel (5 cents). Coin values are not proportional to size.

content.text: Displayed prices in US stores typically exclude sales tax. Tax is calculated and added at checkout, making the final price higher than the displayed price.
details: Sales tax rates vary by state (0% to over 10%)
Some states have no sales tax: Oregon, Montana, New Hampshire, Delaware
Cities may add additional local taxes
Some items may be tax-exempt (groceries, medicine) depending on state
content.practical_tip: Budget 5-10% above displayed prices for sales tax.

lessons.title: Checking Accounts
learning_objectives: Understand the purpose and features of checking accounts
Know what documents are required to open an account
Understand key terms: routing number, account number, direct deposit
Recognize and avoid common fees

content.definition: A checking account is a deposit account designed for frequent transactions including deposits, withdrawals, and payments.
primary_uses: Paying bills (online, automatic, or by check)
Making purchases with a linked debit card
Transferring money to other accounts or people
content.key_characteristic: Designed for liquidity and frequent access, not for earning interest.

required_documents: Proof of address (utility bill, lease agreement, or official letter)
Social Security Number (SSN) or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN)
where_to_open: Traditional banks: Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Citibank
Credit unions: Often lower fees, membership requirements apply
Online banks: Ally, Discover, Capital One 360

terms.definition: A 9-digit code identifying the financial institution. Used for direct deposits, wire transfers, and electronic payments.
Unique number identifying your specific account. Combined with routing number to receive funds.
Electronic transfer of funds directly into your account, typically used for payroll.
Occurs when you spend more than your available balance. Results in negative balance and typically incurs fees of $25-$35.

rows: Maintain minimum balance, set up direct deposit, or use student account
Track balance, set up alerts, link to savings for protection
Use your bank's ATM network, get cash back at stores
Use ACH transfer or Zelle when possible
Higher rates available (4-5% at online banks)
content.recommendation: Maintain both: checking for expenses, savings for reserves.

lessons.title: Savings Accounts and Interest
learning_objectives: Understand savings account features and purpose
Calculate interest earnings using APY
Compare traditional vs high-yield savings accounts
Understand FDIC insurance protection

content.definition: A savings account is a deposit account that earns interest while keeping funds accessible for goals and emergencies.
APY (Annual Percentage Yield) represents the total interest earned on deposits over one year, including compound interest.

content.recommendation: High-yield savings accounts offer significantly better returns with the same protections.

content.what_it_is: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) insures deposits at member banks.
content.coverage: $250,000 per depositor, per insured bank, per ownership category
content.verification: Look for 'Member FDIC' on bank materials.

lessons.title: Using Debit Cards
learning_objectives: Understand how debit cards work
Know the difference between PIN and signature transactions
Implement security best practices
Know what to do if card is lost or stolen

content.definition: A debit card is linked to your checking account and allows you to spend money directly from your balance.
transaction_process: Card is swiped, inserted, or tapped
Transaction is authorized against your balance
Funds are deducted from checking account
content.key_distinction: Unlike credit cards, debit cards use YOUR money, not borrowed funds.

content.explanation: When using a debit card at checkout, you may be asked to select 'debit' or 'credit'. Both withdraw from your checking account.
content.clarification: Selecting 'credit' does NOT charge a credit card. It changes how the transaction is processed.

pin_security: Never share your PIN with anyone
Do not write PIN on card or store in wallet
Cover keypad when entering PIN in public
Choose a PIN that is not easily guessed
general_security: Enable transaction alerts via mobile app
Use mobile wallet (Apple Pay, Google Pay) for added security
Be cautious of card skimmers at ATMs

content_blocks.title: If Your Card is Lost or Stolen

immediate_steps: Lock/freeze card immediately through mobile banking app
Report the loss and request card cancellation
Review recent transactions for unauthorized charges

lessons.title: Understanding and Avoiding Bank Fees
learning_objectives: Identify common bank fees and their costs
Implement strategies to avoid unnecessary fees
Understand fee waiver conditions

rows: Payment bounces due to insufficient funds
Using ATM outside your bank's network

waiver_options: Choose an online bank with no monthly fees

prevention: Track spending and check balance before purchases
Link savings account for overdraft protection
Opt out of overdraft coverage (transactions will decline instead)

strategies: Get cash back at grocery stores (no fee)
Choose a bank that reimburses ATM fees

content.scenario: Potential annual cost if not managed
content.message: Most of these fees are avoidable with proper account management.

modules.name: Credit Fundamentals
modules.description: Understanding the US credit system, credit scores, and building credit history

lessons.title: Introduction to Credit
learning_objectives: Define credit and understand its role in the US financial system
Recognize situations where credit history is evaluated
Distinguish between having no credit and having bad credit

content.definition: Credit is the ability to borrow money or access goods and services with the agreement to pay later, typically with interest.
forms_of_credit: Credit cards: Revolving credit for purchases
Auto loans: Installment loan for vehicle purchase
Mortgages: Loan secured by real estate
Student loans: Loans for education expenses
Personal loans: Unsecured loans for various purposes

content_blocks.title: Why Credit Matters in the US

content.text: The US financial system relies heavily on credit history to assess trustworthiness.

where_credit_is_checked.impact: Landlords review credit to assess reliability
Credit score directly affects interest rate
Determines approval, credit limit, and interest rate
Carriers may require deposits without credit history
In many states, credit affects auto and home insurance rates
Some employers check credit for positions involving financial responsibility
Credit score is a primary factor in approval and rate

no_credit.definition: No US credit history exists. Credit bureaus have no record of your borrowing behavior.
no_credit.typical_situation: New arrivals to the US, young adults who have not used credit
no_credit.implication: Lenders cannot assess risk, but there is no negative history. Building credit is straightforward.

bad_credit.definition: Credit history exists but shows negative patterns: late payments, defaults, collections, or bankruptcy.
bad_credit.implication: Lenders view as high risk. Rebuilding takes time and consistent positive behavior.

content.key_point: Starting with no credit history is not the same as having damaged credit.

lessons.title: Understanding Credit Scores
learning_objectives: Understand credit score ranges and what they mean
Know the three major credit bureaus
Access free credit reports and scores

content.definition: A credit score is a three-digit number (typically 300-850) that represents creditworthiness based on credit history.
content.most_common_model: FICO Score (used in 90%+ of lending decisions)
content.alternative_model: VantageScore (used by some lenders and free monitoring services)

rows: Best rates and terms, easy approval
Better than average rates, high approval odds
Acceptable to most lenders, average rates

content.explanation: Three companies collect and maintain credit information in the US.
content.why_scores_differ: Not all lenders report to all three bureaus, and timing varies.

free_credit_reports.frequency: One free report from each bureau per year
free_credit_reports.contains: Detailed credit history but NOT the score

sources: Many credit cards provide free FICO scores

content.recommendation: Check reports annually for errors. Monitor score monthly through free services.

content_blocks.title: How Credit Score Affects Loan Costs

content.difference: A lower credit score can cost nearly $10,000 more on the same loan.

lessons.title: Factors That Determine Your Credit Score
learning_objectives: Understand the five FICO score components and their weights
Learn how to positively influence each factor
Recognize actions that damage credit scores

content.overview: Your credit score is calculated from five categories of information.

components.description: Record of on-time and late payments
Percentage of available credit being used
Age of oldest account, newest account, and average age
Variety of credit types (cards, loans, mortgage)
Recent credit applications and new accounts

content.impact_of_late_payment: A single 30-day late payment can drop your score 50-100+ points
content.how_long_it_stays: Late payments remain on report for 7 years
best_practices: Set up autopay for at least minimum payments
Create calendar reminders before due dates
If you will be late, call creditor before due date

content.calculation: Utilization = (Total Balances / Total Credit Limits) x 100
tips: Pay balance before statement closes for lowest reported utilization
Utilization has no memory - reducing it improves score immediately

content_blocks.title: Actions That Help vs Hurt Your Score

helps_score: Having a mix of credit types
hurts_score: Applying for many new accounts quickly

lessons.title: Building Credit from Zero
learning_objectives: Understand strategies for building credit with no history
Know how secured credit cards work
Create a timeline for credit building

primary_methods.how_it_works: You provide a refundable security deposit ($200-$500) that becomes your credit limit. Use card normally and pay on time. After 6-12 months, you may qualify for unsecured cards.
primary_methods.best_for: Primary method for those with no credit history

primary_methods.how_it_works: Someone with good credit adds you to their credit card account. Their payment history on that account appears on your credit report.
primary_methods.considerations: Only works if primary holder has good habits.

primary_methods.how_it_works: You make fixed payments to a lender who holds the funds. At end of term, you receive the money. Payments are reported to credit bureaus.
primary_methods.offered_by: Credit unions, some banks, services like Self

primary_methods.how_it_works: Credit cards designed for students with limited or no credit history.

how_it_works: Apply for secured card and provide deposit ($200-$500)
Deposit becomes your credit limit
Use card for regular small purchases
Pay statement balance in full each month
Card issuer reports your activity to credit bureaus
After 6-12 months, request upgrade to unsecured card
Receive deposit back when closing or upgrading
best_practices: Pay full balance by due date

milestones.action: Make small purchases, pay in full
Consider credit builder loan or second card

content.note: Timeline assumes consistent on-time payments and low utilization.

mistakes.mistake: Applying for multiple cards at once
mistakes.instead: Apply for one card, wait 6+ months

mistakes.mistake: Carrying a balance to build credit
mistakes.why_harmful: Myth. Paying interest does not help your score.
Single late payment can drop score 50-100 points

lessons.title: Credit Card Fundamentals
learning_objectives: Understand how credit card billing works
Calculate interest charges
Use credit cards responsibly to avoid debt

content.definition: A credit card allows you to borrow money from the card issuer for purchases. You must repay what you borrow, plus interest if you do not pay in full.

billing_cycle.statement_date: End of billing cycle, balance is totaled
billing_cycle.grace_period: Time between statement and due date where no interest accrues if previous balance was paid

content.key_principle: Pay statement balance in full by due date to avoid all interest charges.

terms.definition: Annual Percentage Rate - yearly interest rate on unpaid balances. Typically 15-25%+.
Total charges from the previous billing cycle. Pay this in full to avoid interest.
Smallest amount required to keep account in good standing. Typically 1-3% of balance or $25.
Maximum amount you can borrow on the card.
Using credit card to withdraw cash. Incurs immediate interest and fees. Avoid.

content.scenario: $1,000 balance at 22% APR, paying only minimum
content.lesson: Minimum payments are designed to keep you in debt. Always pay more than minimum.

content_blocks.title: Responsible vs Irresponsible Credit Card Use

rows: Pay statement balance in full monthly
Use for planned purchases within budget
Result: Build credit, earn rewards, pay $0 interest
Result: High interest debt, damaged credit

types.how_it_works: Earn points redeemable for travel, merchandise

content.critical_warning: Rewards are worthless if you carry a balance. 2% cash back is meaningless against 22% interest.

modules.name: Money Management
modules.description: Budgeting, saving strategies, and managing debt effectively

lessons.title: Creating and Maintaining a Budget
learning_objectives: Understand the purpose and benefits of budgeting
Apply the 50/30/20 budgeting framework
Track income and expenses effectively

content.definition: A budget is a plan for how you will allocate your income across expenses, savings, and other financial goals.

content.overview: A simple guideline for allocating after-tax income
content.flexibility: These are guidelines. Adjust based on your situation and cost of living.

steps.title: Calculate monthly after-tax income
steps.detail: Use take-home pay, not gross salary

steps.title: Track current spending for 30 days
steps.detail: Use bank and credit card statements

steps.title: Categorize expenses
steps.detail: Group into needs, wants, and savings

steps.title: Compare to 50/30/20 targets
steps.detail: Identify areas over or under budget

steps.title: Set specific limits for each category
Automate where possible
steps.detail: Automatic transfers to savings, automatic bill pay

lessons.title: Building an Emergency Fund
learning_objectives: Understand the purpose of an emergency fund
Determine appropriate emergency fund size
Know where to keep emergency funds

content.definition: Money set aside specifically to cover unexpected financial emergencies.
purpose: Cover unexpected expenses without using credit cards
Provide income replacement during job loss
Prevent debt spiral from unexpected costs

calculating_target.formula: Monthly essential expenses x number of months
calculating_target.essential_expenses: Rent, utilities, food, insurance, minimum debt payments, transportation

content.best_option: High-yield savings account at online bank

why_not_other_options.checking_account: Too accessible, likely to be spent
why_not_other_options.investments: Value can decrease when you need money

strategies.how: Set up automatic transfer on payday

lessons.title: Managing and Eliminating Debt
learning_objectives: Distinguish between different types of debt
Understand debt avalanche and debt snowball methods
Create a debt repayment plan

moderate_interest_debt.priority: Pay on schedule, consider extra payments

low_interest_debt.priority: Pay minimum, may not need to pay extra

methods.name: Debt Avalanche
methods.cons: May take longer to see progress

content.both_require: Making at least minimum payments on all debts

avalanche_order: Put extra $200 toward Credit Card A (highest rate)
When A paid off, redirect $275 to Credit Card B
When B paid off, redirect $315 to Car Loan

traps.danger: Takes years, costs multiples of original
Promo rate ends, high rate applies
traps.alternative: Only transfer if you can pay off in promo period

modules.name: US Tax Essentials
modules.description: Understanding and navigating the US tax system

lessons.title: How the US Tax System Works
learning_objectives: Understand the types of taxes in the US
Know how progressive tax brackets work
Understand the difference between tax deductions and credits

taxes.no_tax_states: Alaska, Florida, Nevada, South Dakota, Texas, Washington, Wyoming

content.explanation: The US uses marginal tax brackets. You pay different rates on different portions of income.
content.key_point: Moving into a higher bracket does not mean all income is taxed at the higher rate.

deductions.effect: Save money equal to deduction x your marginal tax rate

types.itemized: Individual deductions (mortgage interest, state taxes, charity)

credits.definition: Directly reduce your tax bill dollar-for-dollar
credits.effect: Save exact amount of the credit

content.comparison: Credits are more valuable than deductions of the same amount.

rows: Deadline to file extension (more time to file, NOT to pay)
Deadline for those who filed extension

lessons.title: Filing Your Tax Return
learning_objectives: Know what documents are needed to file
Understand filing options and costs
Complete a basic tax return

required.what: From each employer, shows wages and taxes withheld

if_applicable.what: For freelance income, bank interest, investments
Mortgage interest, student loan interest, tuition

steps.options: Single, Married Filing Jointly, Married Filing Separately, Head of Household

steps.action: Pay any tax owed OR receive refund

refund.what: You overpaid taxes during the year

owing.what: You underpaid taxes during the year
owing.meaning: You must pay the difference by April 15

content.ideal: Break even or small refund/balance due. Large refund means you gave government interest-free loan.

lessons.title: Tax Identification Numbers
learning_objectives: Understand the difference between SSN and ITIN
Know how to apply for each

rows: US citizens, permanent residents, work-authorized visa holders
Anyone who needs to file US taxes but is ineligible for SSN

content.eligibility: Must have work authorization in the US

steps.action: Wait at least 10 days after US arrival
Visit local Social Security Administration office

best_practices: Do not carry Social Security card in wallet
Only provide SSN when absolutely necessary
Shred documents containing SSN before discarding
Monitor credit reports for signs of misuse
Never share SSN via email or over phone unless you initiated contact

modules.name: Investing Fundamentals
modules.description: Building wealth through investing in stocks, bonds, and funds

lessons.title: Introduction to Investing
learning_objectives: Understand the difference between saving and investing
Know the relationship between risk and return
Understand compound growth

content.principle: Higher potential returns generally require accepting higher risk

content.definition: Compound growth means you earn returns on your returns
content.lesson: Time in the market matters more than timing the market.

prerequisites.exception: 401k match is worth getting even with some debt

lessons.title: Stocks and Bonds
learning_objectives: Understand what stocks and bonds represent
Know key differences between them
Understand why index funds are recommended

content.definition: A stock represents partial ownership in a company.
A bond is a loan you make to a government or corporation.
how_it_works: You buy bond for $1,000
Issuer pays you interest periodically
At maturity, you receive original $1,000 back

content.definition: A fund that holds all stocks in a market index (like S&P 500)
benefits: Instant diversification (hundreds of companies in one purchase)
Beats most actively managed funds over time
content.recommendation: For most investors, low-cost index funds are the optimal choice.

lessons.title: Diversification
learning_objectives: Understand why diversification matters
Know how to diversify a portfolio
Understand asset allocation by age

content.definition: Spreading investments across different assets so poor performance in one area is offset by others

types.what: Mix of stocks, bonds, real estate
Large cap, mid cap, small cap

content.definition: How you divide investments between stocks, bonds, and other assets
content.key_factor: Time horizon - how long until you need the money

lessons.title: 401(k) Plans
learning_objectives: Understand how 401(k) plans work
Know the importance of employer matching
Understand contribution limits

content.definition: Employer-sponsored retirement savings plan with tax advantages
how_it_works: Money deducted from paycheck before taxes (Traditional) or after (Roth)
You choose investments from plan options
Money grows tax-advantaged until retirement

types.traditional_401k: Contributions reduce taxable income now; withdrawals taxed in retirement
types.roth_401k: Contributions from after-tax income; withdrawals tax-free in retirement

content.what_it_is: Employers contribute additional money based on your contributions
content.critical_point: Always contribute at least enough to get the full employer match.

lessons.title: Individual Retirement Accounts
learning_objectives: Understand differences between Traditional and Roth IRAs
Know contribution limits and eligibility

rows: Yes - phases out at higher incomes

lessons.title: Roth vs Traditional Accounts
learning_objectives: Understand when to choose Roth vs Traditional
Develop a strategy using both account types

content_blocks.title: The Core Question: When to Pay Taxes

traditional.best_when: Current tax rate is HIGHER than expected retirement rate

roth.best_when: Current tax rate is LOWER than expected retirement rate

content.recommendation: Use both account types for tax diversification
typical_approach: Contribute to 401(k) up to employer match

modules.name: Insurance Essentials
modules.description: Protecting yourself with appropriate insurance coverage

lessons.title: Understanding Insurance
learning_objectives: Understand the purpose of insurance
Know key insurance terminology
Identify types of insurance

content.definition: A contract where you pay premiums in exchange for financial protection against specific losses.
how_it_works: You pay regular premiums
If covered event occurs, insurance pays for damages
You pay deductible first
Insurance covers costs up to policy limits

terms.definition: Amount you pay before insurance kicks in
Fixed amount for specific services (health insurance)
Percentage you pay after meeting deductible

rows: Recommended if others depend on you

lessons.title: Health Insurance
learning_objectives: Understand why health insurance is critical
Know how to obtain health insurance

content.consequence: Medical debt is a leading cause of bankruptcy in the US

out_of_network.cost: Much higher, may not be covered

content.action: Always verify provider is in-network before receiving care.

lessons.title: Renters Insurance
learning_objectives: Understand what renters insurance covers
Know typical costs

coverage_types.protects: Belongings against theft, fire, water damage
You if someone is injured in your rental
Costs if you must live elsewhere temporarily

modules.name: Consumer Protection
modules.description: Protecting yourself from scams and understanding your rights

lessons.title: Protecting Yourself from Scams
learning_objectives: Recognize common scams
Identify red flags
Know how to report scams

scams.name: IRS/Government Impersonation
scams.how: Caller demands immediate payment, threatens arrest
scams.reality: IRS always contacts by mail first

scams.name: Immigration Scam
scams.how: Email about visa problems, requests payment
scams.reality: USCIS does not contact via email

scams.name: Romance Scam
scams.reality: Never send money to someone not met in person

warning_signs: Unusual payment: Gift cards, wire transfers, crypto
Request for sensitive information via phone/email
Too good to be true offers

immediate_actions: Contact bank if money was sent
Change passwords if account access given

lessons.title: Your Consumer Rights
learning_objectives: Know key consumer protection laws
Understand how to dispute credit report errors

rights: Cannot call before 8 AM or after 9 PM

steps.action: Get free credit reports from AnnualCreditReport.com

modules.name: Major Purchases
modules.description: Making smart decisions on large purchases

lessons.title: Buying a Car
learning_objectives: Understand true cost of car ownership
Know the car buying process
Avoid common mistakes

content.recommendation: Used cars (2-4 years old) from reliable brands often offer best value

steps.action: Determine budget including all ownership costs
Get pre-approved for financing from your bank
Test drive and get independent mechanic inspection
Negotiate on total price, not monthly payment

mistakes.defense: Keep total car costs under 15% of income

lessons.title: Introduction to Home Buying
learning_objectives: Understand basic requirements
Know typical costs
Understand rent vs buy decision

factors_favoring_renting: Planning to stay less than 3-5 years
content.key_point: Renting is not throwing money away. It pays for housing and flexibility.

content_blocks.title: What You Need to Buy a Home

rules.meaning: Housing costs should not exceed 28% of gross income
Total debt payments should not exceed 36% of gross income

content.caution: These are maximums. Borrowing less leaves room for savings.

lessons.title: Introduction to Cryptocurrency
learning_objectives: Understand what cryptocurrency is
Know basic blockchain concepts

content.definition: Digital currency using cryptography for security, operating on decentralized networks.
key_characteristics: Decentralized: No central authority controls it
Transparent: Transactions recorded on public ledger

content.definition: A distributed digital ledger recording transactions across many computers.
how_it_works: Transactions grouped into blocks
Each block linked to previous (chain)
Copies exist on thousands of computers
Makes record highly secure and tamper-resistant

lessons.title: Cryptocurrency Risks
learning_objectives: Understand significant risks
Know how cryptocurrency is taxed
Recognize scams

risks.detail: No FDIC insurance, if exchange fails funds may be unrecoverable
Sent to wrong address = funds gone forever
Fake tokens, rug pulls, phishing common

content.bottom_line: Never invest more than you can afford to lose completely.

content.irs_treatment: Cryptocurrency is treated as property, not currency
content.not_taxable: Buying cryptocurrency with USD (track cost basis)

guidelines: Only invest what you can afford to lose 100%
Limit crypto to 5% maximum of portfolio
Use regulated US exchanges (Coinbase, Kraken, Gemini)
Never share private keys or seed phrases

lessons.title: Setting Financial Goals
learning_objectives: Create specific financial goals
Prioritize goals appropriately

framework.good_example: Pay off $3,000 credit card by December 31

lessons.title: Tracking Your Net Worth
learning_objectives: Calculate net worth
Track net worth over time

content.definition: Total value of everything you own minus everything you owe.

assets.definition: Things you own with monetary value

content.interpretation: Negative net worth is common early in career. Focus on the trend over time.
